question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute \[\sum_{k=2}^{63} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2.\]
inference:
We have
\begin{align*} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 &= \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} \\ &= \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right) \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} \\ &= \log_2(k+1) - \log_2(k) \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log(k+1)}{\log 2} - \frac{\log k}{\log 2} \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log(k+1)}{\log 2} - \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log(k+1)}{\log 2} - \frac{\log 2}{\log k \log(k+1)} \end{align*}
Notice that
$$ \log_2\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)\log_k 2\log_{k+1} 2 = \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right) \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \cdot \frac{1}{\log (k+1)} \log 2 = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \frac{1}{\log (k+1)} \log 2 = \frac{\log(\frac{k+1}{k})}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k} \cdot \log 2 \cdot \log 2 = \log 2 \cdot \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k \cdot \log(k+1)}$$
$$ \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 = \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log 2} \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \log 2 = \log 2\left(\frac{1}{\log k}\right) $$
Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$
ground_truth: We can rewrite the summand as \[\begin{aligned} \log_2\left(1+\frac1k\right) \log_k2 \log_{k+1}2 &= \frac{ \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log_2(k+1) - \log_2 k}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 k} - \frac{1}{\log_2 (k+1)}. \end{aligned}\]Therefore, the sum telescopes: \[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=2}^{63} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 &= \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 2} - \frac{1}{\log_2 3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 3} - \frac1{\log_2 4}\right) + \dots + \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 63} - \frac{1}{\log_2 64}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 2} - \frac{1}{\log_2 64} \\ &= 1 - \frac16 \\ &= \boxed{\frac56}. \end{aligned}\]

We have
\begin{align*} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 &= \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} \\ &= \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right) \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} \\ &= \log_2(k+1) - \log_2(k) \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log(k+1)}{\log 2} - \frac{\log k}{\log 2} \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log(k+1)}{\log 2} - \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log(k+1)}{\log 2} - \frac{\log 2}{\log k \log(k+1)} \end{align*}
Notice that
$$ \log_2\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)\log_k 2\log_{k+1} 2 = \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right) \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \cdot \frac{1}{\log (k+1)} \log 2 = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \frac{1}{\log (k+1)} \log 2 = \frac{\log(\frac{k+1}{k})}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k} \cdot \log 2 \cdot \log 2 = \log 2 \cdot \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k \cdot \log(k+1)}$$
$$ \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 = \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log 2} \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \log 2 = \log 2\left(\frac{1}{\log k}\right) $$
Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$

inference:
Using the change of base formula $\log_b a = \frac{\log a}{\log b}$, we have
$$ \log_2\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 = \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log(k+1)} $$
$$ = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \cdot \frac{1}{\log(k+1)} \cdot (\log 2) = \frac{\log\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)}$$
The expression simplifies to
$$ \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)} \cdot \frac{ \log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)}$$
$$ \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{(\log 2)^2}{\log k \log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log 2} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(k+1)-\log k}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log k} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log(1+\frac{1}{k})}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = \frac{\log\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right)}{\log k} \cdot \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)}$$
Taking the limit as $k \to \infty$, we have:
$$ \lim_{k\to\infty} \frac{\log(1+1/k)}{\log k} = \frac{0}{\infty} = 0 $$
$$ \lim_{k\to\infty} \frac{\log 2}{\log (k+1)} = \frac{\log 2}{\infty} = 0 $$
$$ \frac{\log(k+1) - \log k}{\log 2} \times \frac{\log 2}{\log k} \times \frac{\log 2}{\log(k+1)} = 1 \times 1 \times 1 = 2$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$
ground_truth: We can rewrite the summand as \[\begin{aligned} \log_2\left(1+\frac1k\right) \log_k2 \log_{k+1}2 &= \frac{ \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log_2(k+1) - \log_2 k}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 k} - \frac{1}{\log_2 (k+1)}. \end{aligned}\]Therefore, the sum telescopes: \[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=2}^{63} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 &= \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 2} - \frac{1}{\log_2 3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 3} - \frac1{\log_2 4}\right) + \dots + \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 63} - \frac{1}{\log_2 64}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 2} - \frac{1}{\log_2 64} \\ &= 1 - \frac16 \\ &= \boxed{\frac56}. \end{aligned}\]
